posts.name:
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
posts.content:
𝗧𝗵𝗲 “𝗜 𝗱𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼, 𝗜 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼” 𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱𝘀𝗲𝘁

It’s easy to feel overwhelmed by life’s tasks, but how we approach them can change everything.

Here’s a small shift that can have a big impact:
Instead of saying “I have to,” try saying “I get to.”

This simple change can transform your daily responsibilities into opportunities for growth and gratitude.

When you say “I get to,” you’re embracing the opportunity to:
️ Show up with intention.
️ Appreciate the simple things.
️ Cultivate positivity and joy.

Shifting our mindset isn’t always easy, but it’s a choice we can make every day.

By framing tasks as privileges, we move from feeling burdened to feeling empowered.

 Tell me in the comments—how will you use this shift in your life today?
️ Share this to inspire someone else to reframe their mindset.
 Follow me for more insights on building a positive and fulfilling life.

comments.commentText:
And remember: every task, big or small, contributes to the bigger picture of your life.
️ That email you 'get to' send might build a connection.
️ That workout you 'get to' do strengthens your body and mind.
️ That job you 'get to' show up for supports your dreams.
Small shifts lead to massive changes over time.
 The mindset of gratitude isn’t just a practice—it’s a superpower.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

comments.commentText: How will you use this shift in your life today?

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but it’s not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

It’s an internal step for:
– The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
– The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
– An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

It’s overlooked because:
– The SDR wants to hit quota.
– The sales manager wants to hit quota.
– Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if you’re serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isn’t the right fit.

Here’s why…

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that “ICP fray” was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as “nontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data sets”.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
– A scooter company managing location data.
– An HR team managing employee data.

They didn’t have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as “a slow death of a thousand cuts.”

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who don’t fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? ️ Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

posts.name:

posts.content:
🆗 𝗤𝗔 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗥𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗪𝗮𝘆: 𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗫𝗲𝗿𝗽 𝘁𝗼 𝗛𝗶𝗶𝗕𝗼

𝗧𝗼𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀 𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁 𝗤𝗔 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮 𝗯𝘂𝗴-𝗵𝘂𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘁𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵𝘁—𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝗾𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗮𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗮 𝗻𝗲𝘅𝘂𝘀 𝗼𝗳 𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗵𝘆, 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝘂𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗶𝘁𝘆. 𝗪𝗲 𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝘄𝗼 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵 𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝗻𝗲𝗫𝗲𝗿𝗽, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗻𝗼𝘄 𝘄𝗲’𝗿𝗲 𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗹𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗛𝗶𝗶𝗕𝗼, 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗺𝗲𝗺𝗼𝗿𝘆-𝗱𝗿𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗻 𝗔𝗜 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺.

𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗶𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝘄𝗲𝗲𝘁 𝘀𝗽𝗼𝘁: 𝗲𝗻𝗼𝘂𝗴𝗵 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗰𝗵 𝗶𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗲𝘀, 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝘀𝗼 𝗺𝘂𝗰𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗱𝗿𝗼𝘄𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗮𝗽𝗲. 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗯𝗶𝗻𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗴𝗼𝗼𝗱 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝘂𝗱𝗱𝗲𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗤𝗔 𝗯𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲𝘀 𝗮 𝘀𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗽𝗼𝘄𝗲𝗿.

Workflow Automation Guide: Put Your Work on Autopilot

1. What is Workflow Automation?
Workflow automation combines sequential tasks with technology to minimize human input and maximize efficiency.

2. Why Automate Your Workflows?
Save time, boost productivity, improve accuracy, and scale operations efficiently without adding extra resources.

3. Examples of Workflow Automation
From sales lead management to automating HR onboarding, workflow automation supports various business functions seamlessly.

4. How to Get Started
Identify repetitive workflows, select the right tools like Make, customize processes with logic and integrations, and scale gradually.

[Explore more in the post]

posts.name:
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
posts.content:
“Scripts Are A Waste Of Time.”

FALSE

Scripts should NOT be read word for word. (After all, actors are paid VERY good money to read a script well.)

Scripts should create consistency and provide a framework for success.

A good script guides the conversation, ensuring key points are covered while allowing room for personalization and natural flow.

The alternative to having a script? Chaos. Without structure, your sales floor becomes the Wild West, where every rep makes it up as they go.

Scripts ensure everyone is aligned, the message is clear, and prospects feel understood – not overwhelmed.

If you want a sales team that is focused, confident, and effective – start by embracing the power of a great script.

comments.commentText: Scripts ensure you hit the main points, I tend to refer to mine as outlines so there is no confusion.
